values:
After I finished my work today, I spent about three hours going around to shelters - still looking for a dog.  Then I went on this website called Hopalong and Second Chance Rescue and saw three of the cutest dogs.  I've written to the people, but I am waiting for an answer.
The rescue organizations are really pretty remarkable.  There are so many of them and they are vigilant about who adopts their pets.  They have online applications and ask if you will agree to a home visit.  Wow!  It really takes the element of immediate gratification out of the process.  The shelters that are run by the city are different. Although the dogs aren't immediately available, you don't have to wait quite as long.  Mobile adoptions are huge.  A lot of these organizations farm animals out to "foster homes" and then on certain days they bring them all together and hope for the best.

The last time I went and got Sammy we went to the Oakland Shelter, saw him and walked out with him that day.  He became the center of our family - a really fabulous dog.  We had him for 7 years - he was 5 years old when we got him - and just lost him a few weeks ago.  See a picture of him below - in healthier days.  We are really missing him - huge emptiness in the house without him.  Little did we know when we walked into the Oakland SPCA that he would become so important.  I haven't had a dog since I was a little girl and now I can't imagine not having a dog!
I am looking for a very readable (that means non-academic and dense) book on gender and education.  Anybody know any titles?

I met early this morning with my mentor and we went over what I've done and she was happy with the results.  As a reward she gave me a lot more!  I actually like the work I'm doing, I find it fascinating.  There's a lot of work this week with a fast turn around so I'm going to be busy busy busy.
I am really evaluating the difference between working away from home and working from home.  There are definite pros and cons.  Right away I think, "I am never away from work."  It's true.  That's the certain down side. Upside is I can choose when to work, I can't do it in a comfortable position and wear anything I want!
All in all, if there was any way to do my school job from home, I would.

HAPPY BIRTHDAY!!  Many happy returns of the day.  I hope you have a special time to celebrate.
Roxanne, your virtual Oracle buddy.

Well I filled out an application for a couple of Beagles from Beagle rescue. In the meantime I wrote to the Milo Foundation and asked them if they had any Beagles. The woman who wrote back was so negative! She said, in essence, beware of Beagles, they dig, they're noisy, they run off.
Yikes!
I've never heard so many conflicting messages about a breed. Some great some bad.  Diane has told me her experience, anybody else?
On the Oracle front.  I was on the phone with my mentor all day today.  The boss in Chicago sent me more materials to edit and I am just whizzing along.

Working the last few days on editing the lessons and unit tests for the 4-day institute.  On the down time looking at dogs in dog rescue.  We fell in love with a chocolate lab in the pound, but have ultimately decided against it.  He's big at 6 mos. and we have a small yard.  Getting him would mean a bit more activity than we have time for.  Plus our yard is small.  We've decided instead to get two Beagles.  Any stories to share about Beagles?

I spoke with my mentor last night. Work continues at a break neck pace - they are behind and need to catch up. They found a niche for me pretty quickly.  I am reviewing all of the presentation materials and making sure they fulfill certain criteria.  As I review the materials I find I am getting more and more interested in Oracle's 21st Century Institute.  It's a wonderful way to look at lessons and a highly organized way to craft them.  I don't think I can say much more about the materials, but I am impressed. 

My mentor told me Oracle campus is filled up and all new employees are working from home.  So working from home is a new one for me.  It has its ups (comfort) and downs (work is always on my mind), but I'll write more about this as I go along.

The first week of work was great.  I am reviewing Oracle's 21st Century curriculum for it's 4-day institute.  Really amazing and I can't wait to show it to some teachers at school.
As exciting as school was, it's been hard.  We had to put my dog down last night - he had cancer and I am just almost too sad for words.  We got him from the Oakland SPCA when he was 5 and had him for 7 years.  he was such a center to our family and the house is quiet and lonely without him.
A real mixed week - great things at work, sad at home.

Great first day. Worked with my mentor, Lonnie, on writing curriculum for a four-day institute on 21st Century learning skills.  We had a phone meeting with her supervisor in Chicago and tomorrow at 9am we have another.  Going from a school environment to the speed show at Oracle is a culture shock.  I really like the way they regard work - different from school and so different from Nummi where I worked last summer.  I think it's going to be a great summer.

school ends tomorrow ad Oracle begins on Monday.  I am excited to start working on curiculum again.  I really enjoyed it a few years ago.  I learned so much about making lessons meaningful to a worldwide community.  We'll see what the summer brings.  I understand that Oracle is working on 21st Century learning skills and wants to create lessons with the components so it'll be fun to help out.
